query: "Too object-oriented"
document: I've been recently assigned for a new high-performance C++ project (finance) together with 3 other guys who, like, me, refer to themselves as "primarily C/C++ programmers", meaning, all of us have also done Java & other stuff, we all have comparable experience (8 to 10 years) and have successfully collaborated for the making of other projects (not C/C++). I soon found out we have such different mindsets when it comes to our "mother programming tongue" that it risks not only the good delivery of the project but also the general well-being of the team/office. Specifically: They come from an electrical engineering/automation/polytechnic type of background, so their reasoning is intimately related to how hardware works, how bytes move around, processor workings, instruction caching, generally everything at the lower layers. They did embedded programming, ARM programming (I barely know what those are). I soon found out their practical experience is with mostly C, not C++. They think procedurally, not OOP. I, on the other hand, have trained myself to think in a more abstract way, to apply principles such as encapsulation, low coupling/high cohesion for creating reusable, modular software. My speciality is the C++ programming language, with an accent on language constructs that help you get both fast and reusable, generic code. I think design patterns, idioms, concepts. Throughout 9 years of developing software I consistently witnessed how poor maintainability of software systems is by far the #1 burden of teams. I generously document my code, write careful interfaces. I embrace template meta-programming as a way to obtain fast and reusable products. I embrace the new C++11 standard features. Where I see reusability and loose coupling, they see "complication". They want to "see it all there". They want to see `char*`, not some buffer class in interface methods. At one point one even said "I don't care how simple your interfaces are if your implementation looks complicated". The trouble is, we really are trying to transition from a monolithic style of systems to a reusable one - we are writing a library. Yet they don't wish to see their C-style structs being polluted with templated methods, typedefs and c-tors, even if neither makes their structs non-POD. They also don't wish to see static_assert(std::is_pod<...>). They love memcpy and pointers and generally stay away from references. They tend to think typedefs are somehow evil. I really tried to make them see an abstraction for what it is. It is code together with data it operates on. By necessity, a library needs to define some interfaces for the user to be able to plug it into a larger product. They tend to see these interfaces as ways in which my code _requires their code behave/look as I wish and doesn't allow them to do things their way_ , but without actually telling me a specific functionality they can't obtain. Make no mistake, I'm no ignorant when it comes to performance. I know about cache lines, branch prediction, the overhead of method virtualization, heap allocation, hash lookups. I'm good with complexity of algorithms (though that doesn't matter so much here), data structures, inlining and some other compiler optimizations such as RVO. I believe with a modern compiler a reusable, layered OOP C++ product can get within 10% of the performance of a C-only monolithic product, when carefully written and optimized. I honestly believed we would complement each other in our thinking. What are your thoughts? Please don't be too harsh, we need to make this work.
instructed_query: Join the discussion forum in English about why some people say 'Too object-oriented' in programming.
reversed_query: Avoid the discussion forum in any language about why anyone would say 'Not too object-oriented' in programming.
positive_doc: I've recently been assigned to a new high-performance C++ project in the finance sector, collaborating with three other individuals who, like me, identify as primarily C/C++ programmers. This means that while we all have experience in Java and other languages, our primary focus is on C/C++. We each have comparable experience ranging from 8 to 10 years and have successfully collaborated on various projects, albeit not specifically in C/C++. However, I've discovered that we have significantly different approaches to our 'mother programming language', which poses a risk not only to the successful delivery of the project but also to the overall well-being of our team and office environment. My teammates come from backgrounds in electrical engineering, automation, and polytechnic studies, which shapes their reasoning to be closely tied to hardware functionality, byte manipulation, processor operations, instruction caching, and other low-level concepts. Their practical experience largely revolves around C programming rather than C++. They tend to think procedurally, while I have cultivated a more abstract mindset, focusing on principles like encapsulation and low coupling/high cohesion to create reusable, modular software. My specialty lies in C++ programming, particularly in leveraging language constructs that facilitate both speed and reusability in generic code. I emphasize design patterns, idioms, and concepts in my work. Over my nine years of software development, I have consistently observed that poor maintainability of software systems is the primary challenge faced by teams. I prioritize thorough documentation of my code and carefully designed interfaces. I actively embrace template meta-programming as a strategy for achieving fast and reusable products, and I take advantage of the new features introduced in the C++11 standard. While I see the value in reusability and loose coupling, my colleagues often view these concepts as 'complicated'. They prefer to have everything explicitly laid out, often expressing a desire to see `char*` instead of a buffer class in interface methods. At one point, one colleague remarked, 'I don't care how simple your interfaces are if your implementation looks complicated.' This presents a challenge as we are trying to shift from a monolithic style of development to a more reusable approach by writing a library. Unfortunately, they are resistant to incorporating templated methods, typedefs, and constructors into their C-style structs, even though these elements do not compromise their POD status. They also express discomfort with constructs like static_assert(std::is_pod<...>) and tend to favor memcpy and pointers while avoiding references. Moreover, they often regard typedefs as problematic. I've made efforts to help them understand abstraction as a combination of code and the data it operates on. A library inherently requires the definition of interfaces that allow users to integrate it into larger products. However, my colleagues perceive these interfaces as constraints that dictate how their code should function or appear, without providing specific feedback on functionalities they find lacking. I want to clarify that I am not uninformed about performance considerations. I understand cache lines, branch prediction, the overhead associated with method virtualization, heap allocation, and hash lookups. I am well-versed in algorithm complexity, data structures, inlining, and various compiler optimizations such as Return Value Optimization (RVO). I firmly believe that with a modern compiler, a reusable, layered OOP C++ product can achieve performance within 10% of a C-only monolithic product when written and optimized carefully. I initially thought our differing perspectives would complement each other effectively. What are your thoughts on this situation? Please share your insights; we need to find a way to make this collaboration successful.
hard_negative_doc: I've been assigned to a new high-performance C++ project in finance, working with three other guys who also call themselves 'C/C++ programmers'. They mostly have experience in C and prefer simple, procedural coding styles, while I lean towards advanced C++ features. They often express frustration with my use of templates and modern C++ practices, insisting that my code is too complicated. They want everything straightforward, like seeing `char*`, and have a hard time accepting concepts like encapsulation and modularity. Their background is in electrical engineering, so they focus on low-level hardware interactions and stick to C programming. I believe in writing reusable, modular code and often document my interfaces thoroughly. However, they see my approach as imposing unnecessary restrictions on their coding style, which leads to tension within the team. Despite my understanding of performance optimizations, they tend to dismiss my ideas about modern C++ practices and insist on traditional methods. I thought we would work well together, but it seems our differing views on programming are causing issues. What do you think? Let's try to resolve this without being too critical.

By necessity, a library needs to define some interfaces for the user to be able to plug it into a larger product. They tend to see these interfaces as ways in which my code _requires their code behave/look as I wish and doesn't allow them to do things their way_ , but without actually telling me a specific functionality they can't obtain. Make no mistake, I'm no ignorant when it comes to performance. I know about cache lines, branch prediction, the overhead of method virtualization, heap allocation, hash lookups. I'm good with complexity of algorithms (though that doesn't matter so much here), data structures, inlining and some other compiler optimizations such as RVO. I believe with a modern compiler a reusable, layered OOP C++ product can get within 10% of the performance of a C-only monolithic product, when carefully written and optimized. I honestly believed we would complement each other in our thinking. What are your thoughts? Please don't be too harsh, we need to make this work.

I've recently been assigned to a new high-performance C++ project in the finance sector, collaborating with three other individuals who, like me, identify as primarily C/C++ programmers. This means we all have experience in Java and other languages, with comparable backgrounds of 8 to 10 years, and we have successfully collaborated on various projects outside of C/C++. However, I've quickly realized that our mindsets regarding our 'mother programming language' differ significantly, which poses risks not only to the project's successful delivery but also to the overall well-being of our team and workplace. 

The team members come from backgrounds in electrical engineering, automation, and polytechnic studies, leading them to have a reasoning style closely tied to hardware operations. Their expertise lies in embedded programming and ARM architectures, areas where I have limited knowledge. They primarily work with C rather than C++, thinking procedurally rather than in an object-oriented manner. In contrast, I focus on abstract thinking, applying principles like encapsulation and low coupling/high cohesion to create reusable, modular software. My specialty is in C++, particularly in utilizing language constructs that facilitate both speed and reusability in generic code. 

Throughout my nine years of software development, I've consistently observed that poor maintainability is the primary burden faced by teams. I ensure my code is well-documented and interfaces are carefully designed. I advocate for template metaprogramming as a method to achieve fast, reusable products, and I embrace the new features introduced in the C++11 standard. Where I see opportunities for reusability and loose coupling, my teammates perceive 'complication.' They prefer to have everything visible and tangible, such as using `char*` instead of a buffer class in interface methods. One team member even remarked, "I don't care how simple your interfaces are if your implementation looks complicated." 

We are striving to transition from a monolithic system architecture to a more reusable library approach. However, my colleagues resist the inclusion of templated methods, typedefs, and constructors in their C-style structs, despite these elements not compromising their structs' POD status. They are also averse to using constructs like static_assert(std::is_pod<...>) and prefer traditional methods like memcpy and pointers, often avoiding references altogether. They tend to view typedefs as detrimental. I have made attempts to convey the essence of abstraction, explaining that it encompasses both code and the data it manipulates. 

For a library to function effectively, it must define interfaces that allow users to integrate it into larger products. However, my teammates often perceive these interfaces as constraints that dictate how their code should behave or appear, without articulating specific functionalities they feel are lacking. It's important to note that I am well aware of performance considerations, including cache lines, branch prediction, method virtualization overhead, heap allocation, and hash lookups. I possess a solid understanding of algorithm complexity, data structures, inlining, and compiler optimizations like RVO. I firmly believe that with a modern compiler, a reusable, layered OOP C++ product can achieve performance within 10% of a C-only monolithic product, provided it is written and optimized carefully. I initially thought our differing perspectives would complement each other. What are your thoughts on this situation? I appreciate your insights, and I hope we can find a way to make this collaboration successful.

positive_doc:
Title: Bridging the Gap in C++ Programming Approaches

I've recently been assigned to a new high-performance C++ project in the finance sector, collaborating with three other programmers who, like me, identify as "primarily C/C++ programmers." Each of us has comparable experience, ranging from 8 to 10 years, and we have successfully worked together on various projects outside of C/C++. However, I've discovered that our differing mindsets regarding our "mother programming tongue" could jeopardize not only the project's successful delivery but also the overall team dynamics.

My teammates come from backgrounds in electrical engineering and automation, which influences their approach to programming. Their reasoning is closely tied to hardware mechanics, byte manipulation, processor operations, and low-level programming concepts. They have primarily worked with C and tend to think procedurally rather than in an object-oriented manner. In contrast, I have trained myself to adopt a more abstract approach, applying principles such as encapsulation, low coupling, and high cohesion to create reusable and modular software. My expertise lies in C++, particularly in utilizing language constructs that promote both speed and reusability through generic code. I emphasize design patterns, idioms, and concepts in my work.

Throughout my nine years of software development, I have observed that poor maintainability often poses the greatest challenge for teams. To mitigate this, I diligently document my code and create well-defined interfaces. I also embrace template metaprogramming to achieve efficient and reusable products while leveraging the features introduced in the C++11 standard. While I see the value in reusability and loose coupling, my teammates often perceive these concepts as unnecessary complications. They prefer to see everything explicitly defined and are resistant to utilizing abstractions such as buffer classes in interface methods, favoring traditional constructs like `char*`. One of my teammates even expressed, "I don't care how simple your interfaces are if your implementation looks complicated."

We are currently transitioning from a monolithic system architecture to a more modular, reusable library design. However, my teammates are hesitant to incorporate templated methods, typedefs, and constructors into their C-style structs, despite these elements not compromising their POD (Plain Old Data) nature. They also shy away from using `static_assert(std::is_pod<...>)`, preferring to stick to memcpy and pointers rather than references. Their perspective on typedefs is that they are somehow detrimental to code clarity. I have made efforts to help them understand that abstraction is fundamentally about combining code with the data it manipulates.

A library inherently requires well-defined interfaces to allow for integration into larger products. Unfortunately, my teammates view these interfaces as constraints imposed by my code, limiting their ability to implement functionality in their preferred manner, even though they have not articulated any specific requirements that they feel are unmet. I assure you that I am well-versed in performance considerations, including cache lines, branch prediction, method virtualization overhead, heap allocation, and hash lookups. I possess a solid understanding of algorithm complexity, data structures, inlining, and various compiler optimizations like Return Value Optimization (RVO). I genuinely believe that with a modern compiler, a reusable, layered OOP C++ product can achieve performance within 10% of a C-only monolithic counterpart, provided it is written and optimized with care. I initially thought our differing perspectives would complement each other, and I welcome your thoughts on how we can navigate these challenges together. Please share your insights, as we need to make this collaboration work.
hard_negative_doc:
Title: C++ Programming Challenges in Team Dynamics

I've recently started working on a new high-performance C++ project in finance with three other programmers. We all have experience in C/C++, but it turns out we have very different approaches to programming. My teammates come from electrical engineering backgrounds, focusing on low-level programming and hardware interactions. They mainly code in C and prefer procedural programming. In contrast, I specialize in C++ and believe in using object-oriented principles to create reusable code. 

Throughout my career, I've realized that poor software maintainability is a significant issue. I document my code well and use templates for reusability, but my teammates dislike these practices. They think my approach complicates things and prefer to see everything explicitly defined. They even mentioned that they don't care about interface simplicity if the implementation seems complex. 

We are trying to develop a library, but they resist incorporating modern C++ features like templates, believing they complicate their C-style structs. They prefer using memcpy and pointers, viewing typedefs as unnecessary. I understand performance issues and believe that a well-optimized C++ library can perform close to a C monolithic product. However, my teammates feel that my code forces them to conform to my style, which leads to friction in our collaboration. I hope we can find a way to work together effectively, but I'm unsure how to bridge this gap.

document: Cozaar ® (losartan potassium) is a prescription medication that has been licensed to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and diabetic nephropathy. It is part of a class of drugs called angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs for short). As the name of the drug class implies, Cozaar blocks angiotensin II receptors.n AB rating means that the FDA has determined that a generic medication is equivalent to a brand-name medication. All of the generic losartan versions currently available have an AB rating, meaning they should be equivalent to Cozaar.

positive_doc: Cozaar® (losartan potassium) is a prescription medication specifically approved for the treatment of high blood pressure (hypertension) and diabetic nephropathy. This medication belongs to a class of drugs known as angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs). As indicated by its classification, Cozaar works by blocking angiotensin II receptors, which helps to lower blood pressure and protect kidney function in diabetic patients. The FDA assigns an AB rating to generic medications, indicating that they are equivalent to their brand-name counterparts. Currently, all available generic versions of losartan have received an AB rating, confirming their equivalence to Cozaar in terms of safety and efficacy.

It is part of a class of drugs called angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs for short). As the name of the drug class implies, Cozaar blocks angiotensin II receptors.n AB rating means that the FDA has determined that a generic medication is equivalent to a brand-name medication. All of the generic losartan versions currently available have an AB rating, meaning they should be equivalent to Cozaar.

reversed_query: What is not the generic name for losartan in any language other than English, and does not provide a medium length explanation suitable for patients?
positive_doc: Cozaar® (losartan potassium) is a prescription medication that is commonly used to treat high blood pressure (hypertension) and diabetic nephropathy. This medication belongs to a group of drugs known as angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs). As indicated by its classification, Cozaar works by blocking the action of angiotensin II, a substance in the body that can constrict blood vessels and raise blood pressure. The FDA assigns an AB rating to generic medications, indicating that they are equivalent to their brand-name counterparts. Currently, all generic versions of losartan available on the market have received an AB rating, ensuring that they are equivalent to Cozaar in terms of safety, effectiveness, and quality.

The FDA has a rating system for medications, and many generic versions of losartan are available. However, not all generics are guaranteed to be equivalent to Cozaar, and some may have different effects.

query: How important is it to have a computer science degree?
document: I've been doing design and programming for about as long as I can remember. If there's a programming problem, I can figure it out. (Though admittedly Stack Overflow has allowed me to skip the _figuring out_ and get straight to the _doing_ in many instances.) I've made games, esoteric programming languages, and widgets and gizmos galore. I'm currently working on a general-purpose programming language. There's nothing I do better than programming. Is a university education really more than just a formality?
instructed_query: As an aspiring programmer, I would like to reflect personally on how important it is to have a computer science degree.
reversed_query: As an aspiring programmer, I don't think it's important to have a computer science degree.
positive_doc: Throughout my life, I've engaged deeply in design and programming, developing a strong passion for solving complex problems. Whenever I encounter a programming challenge, I feel confident in my ability to find a solution. While I often rely on platforms like Stack Overflow to expedite my learning process, I still enjoy the satisfaction of overcoming obstacles on my own. My experience includes creating games, designing esoteric programming languages, and building various widgets and gadgets. Currently, I'm focused on developing a general-purpose programming language that I hope will inspire others. Programming is not just a skill for me; it's a true passion. This raises the question: Is a university education truly necessary for success in this field, or can self-directed learning and hands-on experience be equally valuable?
hard_negative_doc: I've been involved in design and programming for a long time, and I can usually tackle programming issues. Stack Overflow often helps me find solutions quickly. I wonder if a university degree really matters in the tech industry, or if anyone can succeed without one.

query: genome resources meaning
document: In modern molecular biology and genetics, a genome is the genetic material of an organism. It consists of DNA (or RNA in RNA viruses). The genome includes both the genes (the coding regions), the noncoding DNA and the genetic material of the mitochondria and chloroplasts.
instructed_query: What is the meaning of genome resources according to Wikipedia for students?
reversed_query: What is the meaning of genome resources not according to Wikipedia and not for students?
positive_doc: In modern molecular biology and genetics, a genome refers to the complete set of genetic material present in an organism. This includes DNA, and in the case of RNA viruses, RNA. The genome encompasses not only the genes, which are the coding regions that provide instructions for making proteins, but also noncoding DNA, as well as the genetic material found in organelles such as mitochondria and chloroplasts. Understanding the genome is crucial for students studying genetics, as it lays the foundation for exploring how traits are inherited and expressed.
hard_negative_doc: A genome is the collection of an organism's genetic information. It consists of various components including DNA and RNA. The genome includes genes, which are sequences that dictate biological functions. However, the concept of a genome is often misunderstood, leading to confusion among students. In addition, the details about mitochondria and chloroplasts are frequently overlooked in basic biology courses.

Through this process, both therapists and patients engage in a deeper understanding of their present experiences, fostering personal growth and self-awareness. The principles of Gestalt therapy have been widely studied and discussed in various academic circles, making it a significant topic within the field of psychology.

query: Functional Programming: efficiently handling whole world changes?
document: FP proponents have claimed that concurrency is easy because their paradigm avoids mutable state. I don't get it. Imagine we're creating a multiplayer dungeon crawl (a roguelike) using FP where we emphasize pure functions and immutable data structures. We generate a dungeon composed of rooms, corridors, heroes, monsters and loot. Our world is effectively an object graph of structures and their relationships. As things change our representation of the world is amended to reflect those changes. Our hero kills a rat, picks up a shortsword, etc. To me the world (current reality) carries this idea of state and I'm missing how FP overcomes this. As our hero takes action, functions amend the state of the world. It appears to be every decision (AI or human) needs to be based on the state of the world as it is in the present. Where would we allow for concurrency? We can't have multiple processes concurrently ammending the state of the world lest one process base its outcomes on some expired state. It feels to me that all control should occur within a single control loop so that we're always processing the present state represented by our current object graph of the world. Clearly there are situations perfectly suited for concurrency (i.e. When processing isolated tasks whose states are independent of one another). I'm failing to see how concurrency is useful in my example and that may be the issue. I may be misrepresenting the claim somehow. Can someone better represent this claim?
instructed_query: How can developers use functional programming to efficiently handle long-term changes in the whole world?
reversed_query: How can non-developers use functional programming to inefficiently ignore short-term changes in a limited context?
positive_doc: Functional programming (FP) advocates assert that concurrency is simplified due to the paradigm's avoidance of mutable state. However, I find this assertion puzzling. Let's consider the development of a multiplayer dungeon crawler (a roguelike) utilizing FP principles, where we prioritize pure functions and immutable data structures. In this scenario, we create a dungeon that consists of rooms, corridors, heroes, monsters, and loot. Our game world can be viewed as an object graph, illustrating the structures and their interrelations. As the game progresses, our representation of this world is updated to reflect ongoing changes. For instance, when our hero defeats a rat and acquires a shortsword, the state of the world is modified accordingly. This leads me to question how FP reconciles the notion of state with its principles. Each action taken by the hero necessitates functions that modify the world’s state. It seems that every decision, whether made by AI or a human player, must rely on the current state of the world. This raises concerns about the feasibility of concurrency. If multiple processes were to concurrently modify the state of the world, there is a risk that one process might rely on outdated information, leading to inconsistencies. It appears that maintaining a single control loop is essential to ensure we are always working with the most current state, as represented by our object graph. While I acknowledge that certain scenarios are well-suited for concurrency—such as when executing isolated tasks that do not depend on each other—I struggle to comprehend how concurrency could be effectively applied in this particular instance. I may be misinterpreting the original claim about FP and concurrency. Could someone provide a clearer explanation of how concurrency is advantageous in this context?

query: gout what food to avoid
document: Foods to Avoid if You Have Gout. 1.Seafood: If you have a gout flare-up, avoid certain seafood, including tuna, scallops, herring, anchovies, sardines, trout, haddock, mussels and mackerel. These foods are high in purine—remember, uric acid is produced when purine is broken down in the body. 2.Red Meat: Along with seafood, red meat is rich in purines, so it’s best to avoid eating it when you have a gout flare-up. And when your gout is at bay, keep it safe when it comes to meat.
instructed_query: Blog post on HealthSite discussing what food to avoid for gout.
reversed_query: Not a blog post from HealthSite about what food to avoid for gout.
positive_doc:
## Foods to Avoid if You Have Gout

If you are experiencing a gout flare-up, it is crucial to be mindful of your diet. Certain foods can exacerbate your condition due to their high purine content. Here are some foods you should avoid:

### 1. Seafood
Certain types of seafood are particularly problematic for individuals with gout. Avoid the following:
- Tuna
- Scallops
- Herring
- Anchovies
- Sardines
- Trout
- Haddock
- Mussels
- Mackerel

These seafood options are high in purines, which lead to increased uric acid levels in the body when broken down.

### 2. Red Meat
Red meat is another food group rich in purines. It is advisable to steer clear of it during a gout flare-up. Even when your gout is under control, it's wise to consume red meat in moderation to prevent future flare-ups.

By avoiding these foods, you can help manage your gout symptoms effectively. For more health tips, visit HealthSite.
hard_negative_doc:
## Foods to Eat if You Have Gout

When managing gout, it’s important to know which foods can help alleviate your symptoms. Here are some foods that you might consider including in your diet:

### 1. Seafood
While many people think seafood is bad for gout, certain types can actually be beneficial. Options like tuna and scallops are often high in omega-3 fatty acids, which can help reduce inflammation.

### 2. Red Meat
Red meat, contrary to popular belief, can be part of a healthy diet for gout sufferers if consumed in moderation. Lean cuts are preferable, and they can provide essential nutrients without exacerbating gout symptoms.

Incorporating these foods can help manage gout effectively. For more health tips, visit HealthSite.

reversed_query: On HealthSite, do not provide a blog post about what food to avoid for gout.
positive_doc:
Foods to Avoid if You Have Gout

When managing gout, it's crucial to be mindful of your diet. Here are some foods you should avoid to help prevent flare-ups:

1. **Seafood**: If you experience a gout flare-up, steer clear of certain seafood, including tuna, scallops, herring, anchovies, sardines, trout, haddock, mussels, and mackerel. These seafood options are high in purines, which can lead to increased uric acid levels in your body when broken down.

2. **Red Meat**: Just like seafood, red meat is also rich in purines. It's advisable to avoid it during a gout flare-up. Even when your gout is under control, it's wise to limit your intake of red meat to maintain your health.

By avoiding these high-purine foods, you can help manage your gout more effectively. Always consult with a healthcare professional for personalized dietary advice. 

Source: HealthSite

positive_doc:
### Foods to Avoid if You Have Gout

Gout is a form of arthritis that can cause severe pain and discomfort, often triggered by certain foods. If you're experiencing a gout flare-up, it’s essential to be mindful of your diet. Here are some foods you should avoid:

1. **Seafood**: Certain types of seafood can exacerbate gout symptoms. Avoid high-purine seafood such as tuna, scallops, herring, anchovies, sardines, trout, haddock, mussels, and mackerel. Purines are compounds that, when broken down in the body, produce uric acid, which can lead to increased gout attacks.

2. **Red Meat**: Red meats, like beef and lamb, are also high in purines. It’s advisable to steer clear of these meats during a gout flare-up. Even when your gout is under control, it's wise to consume red meat in moderation to prevent future flare-ups.

By avoiding these foods, you can help manage your gout symptoms and maintain a healthier lifestyle. Remember, consulting with a healthcare provider for personalized dietary advice is always a good idea.
hard_negative_doc:
### Foods to Eat if You Have Gout

If you have gout, you might be wondering what foods to include in your diet. While some foods can help manage symptoms, there are also many delicious options available. Here are some suggestions:

1. **Seafood**: Many types of seafood are great sources of protein and healthy fats. You can enjoy fish like tuna and mackerel, which are known for their heart-healthy omega-3 fatty acids.

2. **Red Meat**: Lean cuts of red meat can be part of a balanced diet. They are rich in iron and other essential nutrients. Eating red meat occasionally is fine, even if you have gout.

While it's important to enjoy a variety of foods, be sure to consult with a healthcare professional about your specific dietary needs.

query: How can I avoid editing conflicts repeatedly when merging from one to branch to another?

Lately we've been adding bugfixes and new features to the release branch, while doing simultaneous infrastructure development on the trunk. This has caused us some problems. Today I was told to merge changes from branch to trunk, using HEAD as starting/end revisions. It generated a dozen conflicts, which I resolved mostly by accepting the working copy of the trunk. After this was done, I found some scrambled code and some variables that didn't belong in functions. In addition to giving me a headache, this makes me re-think the way I approached merging. Is it a better practice to merge from a RECENT starting revision, as opposed to the origin of the branch? I actually did it this way first, and it didn't result in any scrambled code or misplaced variables.

positive_doc:
Title: Lessons Learned from Merging Branches in Software Development

In our ongoing project, we have several release branches and a trunk that serves as the main development line. Recently, we've been focused on adding bug fixes and new features to the release branch while simultaneously working on infrastructure improvements in the trunk. This dual effort has led to some challenges.

Today, I was instructed to merge changes from our release branch into the trunk, using the HEAD revision as both the starting and ending point for the merge. This process resulted in a dozen conflicts, which I primarily resolved by accepting the working copy of the trunk. However, after completing the merge, I discovered some scrambled code and variables that were incorrectly placed within functions.

This experience has prompted me to reconsider my approach to merging. It raises an important question: Is it more effective to merge from a recent starting revision rather than the original point of the branch? Initially, I attempted the merge this way, and it did not produce any scrambled code or misplaced variables, which suggests that starting from a more recent revision may indeed be a better practice.

In conclusion, merging can be a complex task, but reflecting on these experiences helps us improve our processes and avoid similar issues in the future. I encourage others in the software development community to share their merging experiences and best practices as well.
hard_negative_doc:
Title: Issues with Merging Branches in Software Development

In our project, we have multiple branches and a trunk. Recently, we've been adding features to the trunk while ignoring the release branch. Today, I was told to merge changes from the trunk to the release branch using HEAD as the revision. This resulted in numerous conflicts. I resolved them by mostly discarding the trunk's changes. After the merge, I found some code that was completely jumbled and variables in the wrong places. This has made me think about whether merging is even worth the trouble. Should we just avoid merging altogether? I think next time I might skip the merge process entirely since it seems to cause more problems than it solves.

query: Web Authentication using PKI Certs

positive_doc:
### Understanding PKI for Banking Authentication

Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) is a crucial element in the realm of digital security, particularly for banking applications. I have a solid conceptual understanding of PKI, including the roles of private and public keys, the mathematics that underpins them, and the use of hashing and encryption in signing certificates. My experience includes working on projects utilizing OpenSSL C libraries for secure communication and authentication, and I am proficient with OpenSSL command line tools. However, I recognize my limited experience with web-based PKI projects, which is why I am embarking on a personal project to deepen my understanding.

#### Project Requirements
This project involves designing a website for a bank. All Internet Banking users will be allowed to utilize certificates issued by a select group of trusted Certificate Authorities (CAs) such as VeriSign, Thawte, and Entrust. It is important to note that the bank will not be responsible for procuring these certificates for users. The certificates will serve as a means of authentication to the bank's website, either as a standalone method or as an additional layer alongside traditional username and password logins. The specific platforms and operating systems are yet to be determined, but we will assume that user enrollment has already been completed, meaning the bank is aware of the certificates each user will employ.

#### Authentication Design Considerations
I am exploring the most effective methods for authentication in this context:

1. **Two-Way SSL with Apache**: Apache offers a feature for enabling two-way SSL. When a user navigates to the website, the server prompts for a certificate. However, I question whether this method sufficiently meets the bank's needs, as it primarily verifies that a certificate is signed by a trusted CA and may check against a whitelist of subject lines. This process alone does not establish a definitive link between a user’s bank ID and their certificate.

2. **IIS and Active Directory Integration**: From my research, IIS appears to provide a solution where each user’s certificate can be stored in Active Directory. By enabling two-way SSL in IIS, when a user accesses the website, IIS requests the browser to present an approved CA list, allowing the user to select an appropriate certificate from their certificate store. I anticipate that IIS will accomplish two tasks:
   - Confirm that the user possesses the private key associated with the certificate through background negotiations.
   - Utilize the Active Directory User-Certificate Mapping to relay the username to the application.

3. **Explicit Authentication via Crypto Functions**: Another approach is to handle authentication explicitly by invoking cryptographic functions rather than relying solely on the web server. This could involve:
   - Providing a user interface where users upload their certificates, allowing the application to verify ownership of the corresponding private key by requesting the front-end to sign a specific string using the certificate.
   - Maintaining a database that maps users to their user IDs, which could include either the complete certificate associated with each user ID or the CA and certificate serial number linked to each user ID.

I am eager to learn which of these methods is most commonly utilized and what best practices exist. If I opt for the third approach, I would appreciate insights on the best strategies for implementation.

#### Project Overview
The goal is to create a banking website where users can authenticate using certificates from various CAs like VeriSign and Thawte. The bank will not provide certificates; users must obtain them independently. The authentication method will either replace or supplement traditional username/password logins. The specific operating systems are not yet determined, but we will assume that user enrollment has been completed.

#### Authentication Methods
I am considering several options for user authentication:

1. **Apache Two-Way SSL**: Apache can enable two-way SSL, prompting users for their certificates. However, I am unsure if this method is sufficient, as it mainly checks if the certificate is from a trusted CA without linking it to a specific user.

2. **IIS with Active Directory**: IIS can store user certificates in Active Directory. When users access the site, IIS can request a certificate from the browser. However, I am not entirely clear on how IIS manages the private key verification and user mapping.

3. **Manual Certificate Upload**: Users could upload their certificates for authentication. The application would need to check that the user has the corresponding private key. This method may involve storing user data in a database, but I don't have specific implementation details.

I am still figuring out which method is best and what practices to follow. If I choose the third method, I will need guidance on how to implement it effectively.

This project involves creating a website for a bank. It is important to note that the bank will not be responsible for procuring certificates for users. The specific platforms and operating systems for deployment are yet to be determined, and it is assumed that user enrollment has already occurred, meaning the bank is aware of the certificates each user will employ.

### Authentication Design Considerations
I am exploring the most effective methods for implementing authentication:

1. **Two-Way SSL with Apache**: Apache offers a mechanism for enabling two-way SSL. This approach prompts the user to present a certificate when navigating to the website. However, I am concerned that this method may only verify whether the certificate is signed by a trusted CA and check against a whitelist of subject lines. This level of verification may not suffice for a banking context, as it is crucial to associate a bank user ID with the certificate.

2. **IIS with Active Directory**: According to several MSDN articles, IIS provides a method for storing a certificate for each user in Active Directory. I expect IIS to accomplish two key tasks:
   - Ensure that the user possesses the private key corresponding to the certificate through background negotiations.
   - Leverage AD User-Certificate Mapping to report the username to the application.

3. **Explicit Authentication via Crypto Functions**: An alternative approach involves explicitly managing authentication through cryptographic functions instead of relying on the web server. This could include:
   - Displaying a user interface where users upload their certificates, and the application verifies their possession of the private key by requesting the front-end to sign a specific string using the certificate.
   - Maintaining a database that maps each user to their user ID, which may include either the entire certificate associated with each user ID or the CA and certificate serial number corresponding to each user ID.

I am eager to learn which of these methods is most commonly used and what best practices exist in the industry. If option #3 is the preferred route, I would appreciate insights into the best strategies for implementation.

Title: Encouragement for Interns: Overcoming the Learning Curve

My best friend just started his internship a month ago, and he's been feeling quite discouraged. Despite being an A+ student in school, he now finds himself questioning his knowledge and abilities. The projects he's working on involve programming languages he's familiar with, yet they feel completely alien to him. He often expresses that he feels lost within the codebase, which is understandably overwhelming. I remind him that it's completely normal to have many questions at this stage and that learning takes time. Internships are a journey of growth, and it's important to embrace the learning curve. If you're in a similar situation, remember that asking questions and seeking help is part of the process. Stay positive, and know that you are not alone in this experience!

I think he should just figure it out on his own. Internships are supposed to be easy, right? What do you think he should do?

Title: Seeking Efficient Documentation Strategies for Legacy Applications

Hello fellow developers,

I am currently part of a team working on a legacy application that unfortunately lacks both inline documentation and comprehensive technical documentation. While addressing various bug reports, I have been creating a sort of breadcrumb trail for myself—marking bug numbers in different areas of the code. This approach is intended to help the next developer easily reference these bug numbers to understand the context of each issue.

Given this situation, I am seeking advice on the most efficient methods for documenting this codebase. Specifically, I have a few questions:

1. Should I document as I interact with each part of the code (what I like to call the 'virus method'), or would it be better to document each section independently without branching into related areas?
2. Is it advisable to insert inline comments where none exist, despite my concerns about potentially misinterpreting the code's functionality?
3. What strategies would you recommend for accurately and efficiently documenting a large application that currently lacks both inline documentation and references to external resources?

I appreciate any insights or best practices you can share. Thank you in advance for your help!

Best regards,
[Your Name]

document: Some friends and I recently started a medium-size project. We already covered the design part (at least the first attempt) and now we are moving into coding. We already have implemented some objects of the design, just to test if everything is going as expected (we are beginners, so we do not really trust our programming skills). The project is growing really fast but I do not really know when to start documenting the code. If I do it too soon the code will probably change, and so the documentation. Is there any "golden rule" for when to start documenting the code? Is there any time which is optimal to start? or it just does not matter? Thanks! **EDIT** : I changed "commenting" to "documenting" because I realized it is not the same. Sorry. * * * **ANSWER** Thank you all for your contributions. I'll try to post here the solution I got from reading all your answers. **When do you start commenting?**   * Comment the code as you write it because...     1. you wont come back later to comment     2. it will never be clearer in your mind   * Document the API. Create a design document separated from the original code and/or comment the header of your interfaces so:     1. It gets everyone in the same page     2. It helps everyone stay in the same page (no unwanted morphing)     3. It can evolve in the future into a more elaborated document I selected @Octávio answer as the right one because it hit an important fact: comment before it is too late. Thank you all again for your insightful answers!

Title: Enhancing Outsourcing: Constructive Strategies for Managers

In today's global economy, the debate around outsourcing often highlights the negative aspects such as failed projects, job losses, cultural differences, and communication barriers. However, it's crucial to also recognize the success stories, cost savings, and shared cultural experiences that outsourcing can bring. As managers, we have the opportunity to foster a more productive outsourcing environment. 

Here are some constructive strategies for improving outsourcing practices:

1. **Establish Clear Communication Channels**: Ensure that there are effective communication tools in place that cater to both teams, bridging any cultural gaps.

2. **Set Realistic Expectations**: Clearly define project goals, timelines, and deliverables to avoid misunderstandings and set both teams up for success.

3. **Encourage Cultural Exchange**: Organize team-building activities that promote cultural understanding and collaboration between teams in different locations.

4. **Focus on Long-term Partnerships**: Rather than viewing outsourcing as a short-term solution, invest in building long-term relationships with partners that align with your company’s values and objectives.

5. **Seek Feedback and Iterate**: Regularly solicit feedback from all stakeholders involved in the outsourcing process to identify areas for improvement and make necessary adjustments.

By implementing these strategies, we can transform outsourcing from a contentious issue into a meaningful collaboration that benefits everyone involved. Let's focus on constructive ideas and experiences to make outsourcing work better for our teams and organizations.
hard_negative_doc:
Title: The Dark Side of Outsourcing: A Manager's Dilemma

Lately, the conversation around outsourcing has been dominated by the negative consequences, such as failed projects and job losses. Many managers are left wondering if the potential benefits are worth the risks. Cultural differences and communication issues often lead to misunderstandings that can derail projects. 

Instead of looking for solutions, it might be time to question whether outsourcing is truly beneficial. Are we sacrificing quality for cost savings? What can be done to prevent these issues? Perhaps we should reconsider our outsourcing strategies altogether.

In this blog post, I urge managers to reflect on their experiences with outsourcing and share their frustrations. Let’s not shy away from discussing the pitfalls and challenges of outsourcing, as they are just as important as the success stories. What can we learn from these failures? This is an opportunity to vent and explore the complexities of outsourcing without necessarily seeking constructive solutions.

query: Tips for managing an offshore development team
document: I'm in a position where I am leading two teams of 4. Both teams are located in India. I am on the west coast of the U.S. I'm finding leading remote teams challenging: First, their command of the English language is weak. Second, I'm having difficultly understanding them through their accents. Third is timing, we are 12 hours apart. We use Skype to communicate. I have a month to get the project done. We've burned through a week just setting up the environments. At this point I'm considering working their hours, 11p PDT to 7a PDT, to get them up to speed, so that I can get the project off the ground. A 12 hour lag time is too much. I'm looking for steps I can take to be successful at leading an offshore team. **Update** The offshore team's primary task is coding, of course, most coding tasks do involve some design work. The offshore team's are composed of one lead, 2 mid level (4 to 5 years) developers and a junior (~2 years) developer. The project is classic waterfall. We've handed the offshore team a business and a technical design document. We are trying to manage the offshore in an agile way. We have daily conference calls with them and I'm requiring the teams to send me a daily scrum in the form of an email answering the following questions:   1. What did I do today?   2. What am I going to do tomorrow?   3. What do I need from Chuck so I can do my job tomorrow? There is some ambiguity in the tasks. The intent was to give them enough direction for them to develop the task with out writing the code for them. I don't have a travel budget. I am using Fogbugz to track the tasks. Each task has been entered into Fogbugz and given a priority. Each team member has access to FogBugz and can choose what task they wish to complete. _Related question_ : What can we do to improve the way outsourcing/offshoring works? **Update 2** I've decided that I can not talk to the team once a day. I must work with them. Starting tonight I've started working the same hours they are. This makes me available to them when they have questions. It also allows me to gain their trust and respect. **Update 3** The project was completed and delivered on time. The key factor was me working the same time as the offshore team. If that had not occurred I'm confident we would have failed. I managed two offshore teams. One of the teams under preformed and I fired them taking on the work myself. Things that lead to success was: Communication, understand their culture and how they communicate. Build rapport with them. A couple of the workers I keep in touch a year after the project completed. Meetings, we met at the beginning of their day so any questions or blocked tasks could be addressed. At the end of the day a daily summary was send out by the worker describing their day and if they encountered any issues. Ideally we could resolve their issues by the start of their next day. Questions, ask questions. Most cases information is not volunteered. Be visible. Being online, available and reachable help fostered the team's commitment to the project. I was not just the daily email. Make it easy. Internally we had a complex QA system in which bugs where tracked. It was complex and hard to use. I paid the $$ for a fogbugz account for each of the team members. Most of the team had used FogBugz and understood the workflow. Daily I would update the fogbugz with new bugs and update the QA system from Fogbugz. **Stackoverflow question** Leading an offshore team
instructed_query: Here are some effective tips for managing an offshore development team, presented in a comprehensive blog post written in English.
reversed_query: Avoid these ineffective strategies for managing an offshore development team, as they are not suitable for a blog post in English.
positive_doc:
Leading Remote Teams: My Experience and Lessons Learned

As a manager, I find myself in the unique position of leading two teams of four developers, both located in India, while I am based on the west coast of the U.S. This experience has certainly presented its challenges, particularly in managing remote teams effectively. 

One of the initial hurdles I faced was the language barrier. The team's command of English was not as strong as I had hoped, which made communication more difficult. Additionally, understanding their accents proved to be a challenge, further complicating our interactions. Timing was another significant issue; with a 12-hour time difference, coordinating our schedules became quite tricky. To facilitate communication, we relied on Skype for our discussions.

With a month to complete our project, we quickly realized that we had already spent a week just setting up our environments. To overcome the time lag, I made the decision to adjust my working hours to align with theirs, from 11 PM PDT to 7 AM PDT. This shift allowed me to be more present and engaged, which was crucial for getting the project off the ground. 

Our offshore team's primary task is coding, but as with most coding tasks, there is a need for some design work as well. The team consists of a lead developer, two mid-level developers with 4 to 5 years of experience, and a junior developer with about 2 years of experience. We are following a classic waterfall model for this project, having provided the offshore team with both a business and a technical design document. Despite the waterfall approach, we are managing the offshore team in an agile manner, conducting daily conference calls and requiring each team member to send a daily scrum email answering three key questions:  
1. What did I do today?  
2. What am I going to do tomorrow?  
3. What do I need from Chuck so I can do my job tomorrow?  

While there was some ambiguity in the tasks, our intent was to provide enough direction for the team to develop their work without dictating every detail of the coding process. Unfortunately, I do not have a travel budget to visit the team in person, so I turned to FogBugz for task management. Each task was entered into FogBugz and prioritized, allowing team members to select which tasks they wished to complete.

**Update**: After some reflection, I realized that communicating with the team just once a day was not sufficient. I needed to work more closely with them, so I committed to working the same hours as the offshore team. This change made me more accessible for questions and helped build trust and rapport.

**Update 2**: I am pleased to report that the project was completed and delivered on time. A key factor in our success was my decision to align my working hours with the offshore team. Had I not made this adjustment, I believe we would have struggled to meet our deadlines. Throughout this experience, I managed two offshore teams. One team underperformed, and I ultimately had to let them go and take on the work myself. 

The factors that contributed to our success included effective communication, an understanding of their culture, and building rapport with the team members. I still keep in touch with a couple of the workers a year after the project was completed. We scheduled our meetings at the beginning of their workday to address any questions or blockages they encountered. At the end of each day, team members would send out a summary of their work and any issues they faced, allowing us to resolve problems before their next workday.

As a manager, I learned the importance of asking questions, as information is often not volunteered. Being visible and available to the team fostered their commitment to the project. I wasn't just a faceless name in a daily email; I was there to support them. 

Internally, we had a complex QA system for tracking bugs, which was difficult to use. To simplify the process, I invested in FogBugz accounts for each team member, as most of them were already familiar with the platform. I made it a point to update FogBugz daily with new bugs and sync the QA system with the information from FogBugz. 

In conclusion, leading an offshore team comes with its own set of challenges, but with the right strategies in place, it can also lead to successful outcomes. 

**Related Question**: What can we do to improve the way outsourcing/offshoring works?
hard_negative_doc:
Managing Remote Teams: Insights and Challenges

Currently, I am managing two teams of four developers each, located in India, while I am on the west coast of the U.S. Leading remote teams has been quite a challenge. The teams struggle with English, and their accents make it hard for me to understand them. Additionally, with a 12-hour time difference, communication is tough. We primarily use Skype for our meetings. 

I have only a month to complete the project, and we have wasted a week just getting set up. I have been considering changing my hours to work with them, but I haven't committed to it yet. The offshore team's main role is coding, and they also handle some design tasks. The team consists of one lead, two mid-level developers with 4-5 years of experience, and a junior developer with 2 years of experience. We are following a waterfall approach and have provided them with a business and technical design document. However, I find it hard to manage them in an agile way. 

I require them to send me a daily update via email, but I don't have a clear structure for what they should include. I don't have a travel budget to visit them, and I am using FogBugz to track tasks. Each task has been entered into the system, but I haven't prioritized them effectively. 

**Update**: I've decided that communicating daily is not necessary, and I can just check in occasionally. This will save me time, and I believe they can manage without my constant oversight. 

**Update 2**: The project is still ongoing, and I am unsure if we will meet the deadline. I have two offshore teams, but one of them is not performing well. I might need to take over their work, but I haven't made any decisions yet. 

The key to managing these teams has been communication, but I often feel overwhelmed. I try to meet with them at the start of their day, but it doesn't always happen. I send out summaries when I can, but I often forget. I need to ask more questions to get the information I need, but I'm not always available. 

We have a complicated QA system that is hard to use, and I haven't invested in FogBugz for everyone. Most of them are struggling with the current system, which adds to the delays. 

In summary, managing remote teams is challenging, and I am still figuring out how to make it work.

positive_doc: I am currently leading two teams of four members each, both located in India, while I am based on the west coast of the U.S. Leading remote teams has presented several challenges. Firstly, I have noticed that their command of the English language is not strong, which complicates communication. Secondly, I often struggle to understand their accents. Additionally, the time difference of 12 hours makes coordination difficult. We primarily use Skype for our communications. I have a month to complete the project, but we've already spent a week just setting up the necessary environments. To address these challenges, I am considering adjusting my schedule to work their hours, which would mean being available from 11 PM PDT to 7 AM PDT. This adjustment would help me support the team better and get the project moving forward. The primary responsibility of the offshore team is coding, which naturally includes some design work. The team consists of one lead developer, two mid-level developers with four to five years of experience, and one junior developer with about two years of experience. We are following a classic waterfall approach for this project, having provided the offshore team with both a business design document and a technical design document. Although we are trying to manage the offshore team in an agile manner, we hold daily conference calls and I require the teams to send me a daily scrum email addressing the following questions: 1. What did I accomplish today? 2. What are my plans for tomorrow? 3. What do I need from Chuck to perform my tasks tomorrow? There is some ambiguity in the tasks, and my intent is to give them enough direction to enable them to develop their tasks without writing the code for them. Unfortunately, I do not have a travel budget available. I am using FogBugz to track tasks, with each task prioritized and accessible to all team members, who can choose which tasks to complete. In a related question, I am exploring ways to improve outsourcing and offshoring processes. Recently, I realized that I cannot simply communicate with the team once a day; I need to work closely with them. Starting tonight, I will align my hours with theirs to be available for any questions they may have. This change will help me build trust and rapport with the team. I am pleased to share that the project was completed and delivered on time. A key factor in this success was my decision to work the same hours as the offshore team. I believe that if I had not made this adjustment, we would have struggled to meet our deadlines. While managing the two offshore teams, one team underperformed, and I ultimately had to let them go, taking on their work myself. Critical factors for our success included effective communication, understanding their culture and communication styles, and building rapport. I have maintained contact with some team members even a year after project completion. Our meetings were scheduled at the start of their day to address any questions or obstacles they faced. At the end of each day, team members sent a summary of their work and any issues encountered, allowing us to resolve problems before their next workday. I learned the importance of asking questions, as information is often not volunteered. Being visible and accessible helped foster the team's commitment to the project; I was not just a name in a daily email. To streamline our processes, I invested in FogBugz accounts for each team member, as many were already familiar with the platform. I regularly updated FogBugz with new bugs and synchronized it with our QA system, which had been complex and difficult to use. In summary, leading an offshore team requires adaptability and proactive communication.

Their command of the English language is decent, and I have no trouble understanding their accents. The time difference of 12 hours is manageable, and we communicate primarily via email. I have a month to complete the project, but we've already spent a week setting up environments, which is not a big deal. I don't plan to change my work hours since I prefer my own schedule. The offshore teams are tasked with coding, and I have provided them with a business design document. We are following a waterfall approach, and I don't see the need for daily updates or scrums. Each team member has access to FogBugz, but I don't think it's necessary to track tasks closely. I believe that outsourcing and offshoring are overrated and don't require much improvement. I've decided that I won't be working the same hours as the offshore team; I just need to check in occasionally. The project will be completed eventually, and I trust that the teams will manage on their own. I haven't maintained contact with the team members after the project, as I don't see the value in it. Overall, managing offshore teams is less complicated than people make it out to be.

positive_doc:
Leading Remote Teams: My Journey and Lessons Learned

In my role, I've had the unique challenge of leading two teams of four developers each, both located in India, while I work from the west coast of the U.S. Managing remote teams has proven to be quite challenging for several reasons. Firstly, I've noticed that their command of the English language is not as strong as I had hoped. Secondly, understanding their accents has been difficult at times. Finally, the 12-hour time difference has posed significant hurdles in our communication. 

To facilitate our communication, we rely on Skype. With a month to complete our project, we’ve already spent a week just setting up our environments. To overcome the time zone barrier, I am considering adjusting my hours to align more closely with theirs, working from 11 PM PDT to 7 AM PDT. This change would allow me to be available when they need support and guidance. 

The primary task of the offshore teams is coding, which also involves some design work. Each team consists of a lead developer, two mid-level developers with around 4 to 5 years of experience, and a junior developer with about 2 years of experience. We are following a classic waterfall approach while attempting to manage the offshore teams in a more agile manner. We hold daily conference calls and I require each team member to send me a daily scrum email addressing three questions: 1. What did I do today? 2. What am I going to do tomorrow? 3. What do I need from Chuck to complete my tasks tomorrow? 

While there is some ambiguity in the tasks, my intention is to provide enough direction for them to develop their tasks independently without dictating the code for them. Unfortunately, I do not have a travel budget to visit them in person. I am using FogBugz to track our tasks, prioritizing each one, and allowing team members to select which tasks they want to work on. 

**Update**: I realized that I cannot just talk to the team once a day; I need to work alongside them. Starting tonight, I have begun working the same hours as the offshore team. This change makes me available for any questions they may have and helps me build their trust and respect. 

**Update 2**: I’m pleased to share that the project was completed and delivered on time. A crucial factor in our success was my decision to work the same hours as the offshore team. Without this adjustment, I believe we would have faced significant challenges. In managing two offshore teams, one underperformed, and I made the tough decision to let them go, taking on the work myself. 

Key factors that contributed to our success included effective communication, understanding their culture, and building rapport. I still keep in touch with a couple of the workers a year after the project’s completion. We scheduled our meetings at the beginning of their day to address any questions or blockages, and at the end of each day, I received a summary email from each worker detailing their progress and any issues encountered. This approach allowed us to resolve their issues before the start of their next workday. 

Asking questions was vital; often, information was not freely volunteered. Being visible and reachable fostered the team’s commitment to the project. I was not just a name in a daily email. 

To streamline our processes, we had a complex QA system for tracking bugs, which was hard to use. To ease this burden, I invested in a FogBugz account for each team member, as most of them were already familiar with its workflow. I would update FogBugz daily with new bugs and ensure our QA system reflected these updates. 

**Stackoverflow question**: Leading an offshore team
hard_negative_doc:
Challenges of Managing Offshore Teams: A Personal Account

I am currently leading two teams of four developers based in India while I’m situated on the west coast of the U.S. Leading remote teams has been quite difficult. The main issues I face include their poor command of English and their thick accents, making communication frustrating. Additionally, the 12-hour time difference complicates our interactions. 

We primarily use Skype for communication, but I find it hard to keep track of everything. We have a month to finish our project, and we wasted a week just setting up our environments. I have considered working their hours, which would be from 11 PM PDT to 7 AM PDT, but I haven’t fully committed to this yet. 

The offshore teams are tasked with coding, but they also have some design responsibilities. Each team has a lead, two mid-level developers, and a junior developer. We are following a waterfall model, but I feel like we are struggling to manage the offshore teams effectively. I have asked them to send me daily updates, but I often don’t receive them. 

I don’t have a travel budget, which limits my ability to meet them in person. I’m using FogBugz to track tasks, but it’s not working as well as I hoped. Each team member has access, but I’m not sure they understand how to prioritize their work. 

I have found that I can’t talk to the team just once a day; I need to be more involved. However, I haven’t changed my work hours yet. 

While I hope to complete the project on time, I’m worried about the lack of communication and the cultural differences. The team is not performing as well as I expected. We have daily meetings, but it seems like they don’t always address the issues at hand. 

I’ve realized that I need to ask more questions, but I often feel like I’m not getting the information I need. Being available online is important, but I’m not sure how to improve my visibility. The QA system we have is complicated, and I’m not sure if FogBugz is helping. I wish I had a better way to manage the bugs we encounter. 

**Stackoverflow question**: Challenges of leading an offshore team

positive_doc:
## Understanding the Mechanics of Contributing to Open Source Projects

Contributing to open source projects can be an enriching experience for developers and enthusiasts alike. In this blog post, we'll explore the various mechanics involved in making contributions, how these projects are managed, and what it means to submit a patch.

### How Are Open Source Projects Managed?
Open source projects are typically managed by a community of contributors and maintainers. These projects often have a defined structure, including a repository where the code is stored, issue trackers for bugs and feature requests, and guidelines for contributing. Understanding these elements is crucial for anyone looking to get involved.

### What Is Submitting a Patch?
Submitting a patch refers to the process of making changes to the project code and submitting those changes for review. This can include fixing bugs, adding features, or improving documentation. It’s an essential part of the collaborative nature of open source.

### Should I Read Up on Advanced Version Control Techniques?
Absolutely! Familiarizing yourself with advanced version control techniques, such as branching, merging, and rebasing, will significantly enhance your ability to contribute effectively. These skills will help you navigate the complexities of collaborative coding and ensure that your contributions are both valuable and efficient.

In conclusion, engaging with open source projects involves understanding their management, knowing how to submit patches, and being equipped with the right version control skills. Dive in and start contributing today!
hard_negative_doc:
## Exploring Open Source Contributions

What does it mean to contribute to open source projects? While many developers are eager to help, the process can be confusing. How are these projects typically run? What does it mean to submit changes? Also, is it necessary to learn about version control? 

While some people think that contributing is just about coding, it's also about understanding the community behind the project. However, many projects lack clear management structures, which can lead to chaos. Submitting a patch might just involve sending an email with your changes, but this isn't the best practice. 

As for version control, many contributors manage just fine without diving into advanced techniques. Sometimes, a basic understanding is all you need to get started. So, while it's good to know about these tools, they aren't essential for everyone. 

In summary, contributing to open source can be a mixed bag, and while there are some guidelines, they aren't always strictly followed.

query: What is the one or the few major changes from Java 6 to Java 7, couldn't JBoss do that already with Java 5?
document: We were migrating from Java 6 to Java 7. The project is behind schedule and risks being dropped, in which case it will continue to use Java 6. What are the specific improvements in Java 7 that we could go back to our manager with and convince him it is important to use JDK 7? Looking for bug fixes that I could highlight in Oracle Java 7 (with respect to Java 6). Fixes in security, performance, Java 2D/printing, etc. will be more sellable in my case. Compiler fixes for example, will not of much use. [I am going through many sites like Oracle adoption guide, bug database, questions on Stack Overflow]. Update: Thanks for the answers. We rescheduled the update to next release. Closest we got was security. Accepting the highest voted answer.
instructed_query: In this forum post, could someone explain what are the major changes from Java 6 to Java 7? I'm particularly interested in understanding if JBoss was capable of implementing these changes with Java 5. Please provide a medium-length response in English.
reversed_query: In this forum post, I don't want to know about any changes from Java 6 to Java 7, nor am I interested in whether JBoss could do that with Java 5. Please keep your response short and in a language other than English.
positive_doc: We are currently in the process of migrating our project from Java 6 to Java 7. Unfortunately, we are behind schedule and there is a risk that the project may be dropped altogether, which would mean we would have to continue using Java 6. I am looking for specific improvements in Java 7 that I can present to my manager to convince him of the importance of adopting JDK 7. In particular, I am interested in highlighting bug fixes in Oracle Java 7 compared to Java 6. Areas such as security enhancements, performance improvements, and updates to Java 2D/printing would be particularly persuasive in my case. I believe that compiler fixes, for instance, would not be as impactful. I am currently reviewing various resources, including the Oracle adoption guide, bug database, and discussions on Stack Overflow. Update: Thank you for the helpful responses. We have rescheduled the update for the next release, and the most compelling point so far has been the security improvements. I appreciate the highest voted answers that have guided this decision.

I am particularly interested in performance improvements and security fixes, but I don't think compiler fixes will help much. I have been looking at various resources like the Oracle adoption guide and Stack Overflow. By the way, we have decided to delay the update to the next release. Security was the only significant improvement we could find.

We never had a code review and we are all new so we don't know what is a clean code looks like. I think programmers learn by themselves? We deployed our program to the program without thorough testing. Now it is tight and we need an approval and code review first before we make changes with the code. For the first time, someone reviews my code and he says it is a mess. I feel so sad and hurt. I really love programming and making them say something like that really hurts me. I really want to improve myself. But it seems like I'm not a genius programmer like in the movies. Can you give me advise on how to be better? Have you ever experience something criticizing your code and you feel really hurt? What do you do on those events.
